title: Fix inappropriate OS toast notifications in chat confirmation widget
body:
Fixes #264315

## Problem

The chat confirmation widget was triggering inappropriate OS toast notifications when there was no active session, particularly during:
- VS Code startup when rendering cached chat content
- Window reloads
- Extension updates

## Root Cause

The issue was in the `showingButtons` getter logic in both `BaseSimpleChatConfirmationWidget` and `BaseChatConfirmationWidget`:

```typescript
private get showingButtons() {
    return !this.domNode.classList.contains('hideButtons');
}
```

By default, DOM elements were created **without** the `hideButtons` class, causing `showingButtons` to return `true` immediately. This triggered the notification logic in `renderMessage()` during widget construction, before `setShowButtons()` was called.

The problematic flow was:
1. Widget constructor creates DOM element (no `hideButtons` class)
2. Constructor calls `renderMessage()` → `showingButtons` returns `true` → notification triggered
3. **Only after** constructor completes, `setShowButtons(!confirmation.isUsed)` is called

## Solution

Add the `hideButtons` class by default during DOM element creation in both base widget constructors:

```typescript
// In BaseSimpleChatConfirmationWidget constructor
this._domNode = elements.root;
this._domNode.classList.add('hideButtons'); // ← Added this line

// In BaseChatConfirmationWidget constructor  
this._domNode = elements.root;
this._domNode.classList.add('hideButtons'); // ← Added this line
```

This ensures:
- `showingButtons` returns `false` during construction → no premature notifications
- `setShowButtons(true)` still works correctly by removing the `hideButtons` class
- All existing functionality is preserved

## Testing

Added unit test to verify:
- Widget initializes with `hideButtons` class (prevents notifications)
- `setShowButtons(true)` removes the class correctly
- `setShowButtons(false)` adds the class back

The fix covers all three widget types: `SimpleChatConfirmationWidget`, `ChatConfirmationWidget`, and `ChatCustomConfirmationWidget`.

title: Fix MCP server configuration overwrite bug in updateConfig method
body:
Fixes an issue where configuring model access for a second MCP server would overwrite the configuration for the first server instead of adding a new entry to the `chat.mcp.serverSampling` setting.

## Problem

When users configured multiple MCP servers with model access, the second server's configuration would completely replace the first server's configuration in `settings.json`. This happened because the `updateConfig` method in `McpSamplingService` was not properly preserving existing server configurations.

**Root cause:**
- The `_getConfig` method returns `mapping: undefined` when no configuration exists for a specific server
- The spread operation `{ ...mapping, [key]: newConfig }` becomes `{ [key]: newConfig }` when `mapping` is undefined
- This overwrites the entire `chat.mcp.serverSampling` object instead of merging with existing entries

## Solution

Modified the `updateConfig` method to:
1. Read the full existing configuration from the target scope using `getConfigValueInTarget(configValue, target) || {}`
2. Merge the new server configuration with existing ones using `{ ...existingMapping, [key]: newConfig }`
3. Preserve all other server configurations when updating a single server's config

**Before:**
```typescript
await this._configurationService.updateValue(
    mcpServerSamplingSection,
    { ...mapping, [key]: newConfig }, // mapping could be undefined
    { resource },
    target,
);
```

**After:**
```typescript
const configValue = this._configurationService.inspect<Record<string, IMcpServerSamplingConfiguration>>(mcpServerSamplingSection, { resource });
const existingMapping = getConfigValueInTarget(configValue, target) || {};

await this._configurationService.updateValue(
    mcpServerSamplingSection,
    { ...existingMapping, [key]: newConfig }, // preserves existing servers
    { resource },
    target,
);
```

## Testing

Added comprehensive test coverage in `mcpSamplingService.test.ts` to verify:
- Adding a second server preserves the first server's configuration
- Updating an existing server preserves other servers' configurations  
- Creating the first server works correctly when no configuration exists

The fix ensures that users can configure multiple MCP servers without losing previously configured server settings.

title: Add double-click to create new chat session in Chat Sessions view
body:
Implements the feature requested in #264515 to allow users to create a new chat session by double-clicking in empty space within the Chat Sessions view, following the same UX pattern as the Explorer view.

## Changes

Added a double-click event handler to the Chat Sessions tree view that:
- Detects when empty space is double-clicked (`e.element === null`)
- Respects the `workbench.list.scrollByPage` configuration setting to avoid conflicts
- Executes the existing `workbench.action.openChat` command to create a new chat session

## Implementation Details

The implementation follows the exact same pattern used in the Explorer view (`explorerView.ts` lines 562-569) for consistency:

```typescript
this._register(this.tree.onMouseDblClick(e => {
    const scrollingByPage = this.configurationService.getValue<boolean>('workbench.list.scrollByPage');
    if (e.element === null && !scrollingByPage) {
        this.commandService.executeCommand('workbench.action.openChat');
    }
}));
```

## User Experience

Users can now intuitively create new chat sessions by double-clicking in empty areas of the Chat Sessions view, matching the familiar behavior from the Explorer where double-clicking empty space creates a new file. This improves discoverability and provides a more consistent experience across VS Code views.

Fixes #264515

title: Add confirmation option before deleting chats in Copilot extension
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, when deleting past chats via Show Chats → Delete (X) in the VS Code Copilot extension, the deletion happens immediately without confirmation. This can cause accidental loss of important chat history due to misclicks.

Feature request:

Add a dedicated confirmation prompt before deleting a chat.

Make this behavior configurable in settings, independent of explorer.confirmDelete.

This would help prevent unintentional data loss while giving users control over their workflow.

title: Restore local model selection (ability to disable models) in VS Code Copilot Chat

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

### Summary
Until the most recent update, Copilot Chat in VS Code allowed users to manually manage which language models were enabled or disabled on their machine. This was extremely useful for avoiding models that produced poor results. However, since the introduction of the **Auto model selection** feature, this option has been removed and is no longer available.

### Problem
- The previous **local model selection** feature is gone, and users can no longer persistently disable models they do not want to use.
- The current **Auto** mode ignores local preferences and sometimes uses models that I do not want.
- The **model picker** only allows temporary manual selection, but there is no persistent local control.
- Users without organization admin rights cannot use Copilot Policies to block models globally.

### Why this matters
- Developers need control over model quality without requiring org-level admin permissions.
- Some models may be slower, less accurate, or unsuitable for specific workflows.
- The removal of local model selection reduces flexibility and negatively impacts developer experience.

### Expected behavior
- Provide a way to **locally manage model availability** in VS Code settings (e.g., `settings.json` or like before), so that Auto mode and manual selection respect this configuration.

### Current setup
- VS Code: 1.104.0
- GitHub Copilot: 1.368.0
- GitHub Copilot Chat: 0.31.0
- Copilot Plan: Business (no org admin rights)

### Additional context
This feature existed before Auto mode and was very helpful. Please consider reintroducing it or providing an alternative for local control.

title: GitHub Copilot Chat - Token expired or invalid: 403
body:
# Copilot Chat Extension Version: 1.371.175

## VS Code Version: 1.103.2 (user setup)
* OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 (Windows 11)
* Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Chat
* Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT 4.0
* Logs:
- ID da solicitação: ec87a3a6-0c7c-4c9c-8d51-bdf3e04e0099

* Erro: token expired or invalid: 403

* Mensagem: "Desculpe, sua solicitação falhou. Tente novamente."

* Data do VS Code: 2025-08-20 16:45:34.255Z

## Passos para Reproduzir:
* Abrir o VS Code com a extensão GitHub Copilot Chat habilitada
* Tentar interagir com o Copilot Chat (enviar uma mensagem/solicitação)
* Receber erro "token expired or invalid: 403" com ID da solicitação
* Comportamento Esperado:
* O Copilot Chat deveria responder normalmente às consultas do usuário.

## Comportamento Atual:
* O chat retorna erro de autenticação (403) indicando problemas com o token.

## Contexto Adicional:
* Extensão aparece como "Habilitado" no VS Code
* Erro ocorre consistentemente ao tentar usar a funcionalidade de chat
* Última atualização da extensão: 2025-09-15, 15:11:10
* Usando conexão SSH (SSH: Matheus)
* Sistema: Windows 11 x64
* Electron: 37.2.3
* Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
* Node.js: 22.17.0
